name: Avalokiteshvara

mythology.greatVow: Vowed not to enter final nirvana until every sentient being across all realms and time is liberated from suffering. Represents the Mahayana ideal that individual liberation is incomplete while others suffer.

shatteredVowLegend.description: After eons of tireless work liberating beings, Avalokiteshvara looked out across the universe and saw that despite his efforts, the ocean of suffering remained vast. The realization caused his head to explode into eleven pieces from anguish of compassion.
shatteredVowLegend.resolution: Spiritual father Amitabha appeared and reassembled him with eleven heads to see and hear suffering in all directions, one thousand arms to reach all beings in need, and an eye in each palm to see with wisdom while acting with compassion.

emanations.tara: Born from his tears of compassion
emanations.kingSongtsenGampo: First dharma king of Tibet, emanation of Chenrezig

mythology.miaoShanLegend: Chinese legend of Princess Miaoshan who refused marriage to help suffering beings, was sentenced to death but the executioner's blade could not harm her. She descended to hell realms transforming them to paradise. When her father fell ill, she offered her own eyes and arms to cure him, revealing herself as Guanyin with one thousand arms and eyes.

title: Avalokiteshvara - The Lord Who Looks Down with Compassion
description: Avalokiteshvara (Sanskrit: 'The Lord Who Looks Down'), known as Guanyin in China, Kannon in Japan, and Chenrezig in Tibet, is the bodhisattva of infinite compassion (karuna). He embodies the compassionate activity of all Buddhas, hearing the cries of suffering beings throughout the universe.
summary: The Bodhisattva of Infinite Compassion who vowed not to enter final nirvana until all sentient beings are freed from Samsara. Most widely venerated bodhisattva in Mahayana Buddhism.
attributes: Hearing the cries of the world

forms.name: Thousand-Armed Form (Sahasrabhuja)
forms.description: 1,000 arms radiating like a sun, each hand bearing an eye in its palm, representing ability to see and respond to suffering throughout all realms simultaneously
forms.origin: Arose from his vow to help all beings - when he realized the immensity of suffering, his head split into eleven pieces from anguish. Amitabha reconstructed him with eleven heads and 1,000 arms.

forms.name: Four-Armed Form (Shadakshari)
forms.description: Most common Tibetan form: first pair holds wish-fulfilling jewel at heart, second right hand holds crystal mala, second left hand holds white lotus
forms.posture: Often in lalitasana (royal ease), crowned with image of Amitabha Buddha

forms.name: Two-Armed Form
forms.description: Simplest representation in Anjali mudra (prayer gesture), holding lotus blossom

forms.name: Eleven-Headed Form
forms.description: Eleven faces arranged in tiers: 3 compassionate (bottom), 3 peaceful, 3 wrathful, 1 fiercely wrathful, topped by serene Amitabha

genderManifestations.male: Indian and Tibetan traditions - masculine principle of active compassion (upaya)
genderManifestations.female: East Asian Guanyin/Kannon - Goddess of Mercy, especially popular since Song Dynasty as White-Robed Guanyin

mantra.meaning: The jewel in the lotus - union of compassion (jewel/mani) and wisdom (lotus/padme)
benefits: Purifies the six realms of existence
Closes the doors to unfortunate rebirths
syllableMeanings: OM - closes door to god realms (pride)
MA - closes door to jealous gods (envy)
NI - closes door to human realm (desire)
PAD - closes door to animal realm (ignorance)
ME - closes door to hungry ghost realm (greed)
HUM - closes door to hell realms (hatred)

practices: Chenrezig Sadhana - visualization practice with mantra recitation
Tonglen (Taking and Sending) - breathing in others' suffering, breathing out happiness
Nyung Ne - intensive two-day fasting and prostration retreat
Mani Retreat - completing 100,000+ recitations of Om Mani Padme Hum
devotionalPractices: Turning prayer wheels inscribed with the mantra
Carving Om Mani Padme Hum on mani stones
Hanging prayer flags bearing the mantra
Offerings of white flowers, water, and white scarves (khata)
temples: Potala Palace, Lhasa - considered Chenrezig's earthly abode
Mount Putuo, China - sacred island of Guanyin
Sensoji Temple, Tokyo - dedicated to Kannon

lotusSutra.content: If innumerable hundreds of thousands of myriads of kotis of sentient beings, experiencing pain and suffering, hear of this Bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara and wholeheartedly call upon his name, the Bodhisattva will immediately perceive their voices and rescue them from their suffering.
lotusSutra.significance: Primary source for Avalokiteshvara's salvific powers and thirty-three manifestations

heartSutra.content: When Avalokiteshvara Bodhisattva was practicing the profound Prajnaparamita, he illuminated the Five Skandhas and saw that they were all empty, thus overcoming all suffering and distress.

karandavyuhaSutra.content: The Bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara descended to the hell realms. As his feet touched the ground of Avici Hell, it became as cool as a lake with blooming lotuses. All beings in hell were immediately liberated.
karandavyuhaSutra.significance: Earliest source of Om Mani Padme Hum mantra, origin of thousand-armed form

tibetanSources.content: In ancient times, when Tibet was covered by a great lake, Chenrezig looked down with compassion and saw that this land would become a place where the Dharma would flourish. Every Tibetan being is under the special care of Chenrezig.

chineseSources.content: Namo Avalokiteshvara Bodhisattva. The Bodhisattva of Great Compassion responds to sentient beings in a myriad of forms.

extendedContent.thirtyThreeManifestations: According to Lotus Sutra Chapter 25, Avalokiteshvara takes 33 different forms to save beings according to their needs: Buddha, pratyekabuddha, shravaka, Brahma, various devas, laypeople, children, etc.

historicalContext.description: Avalokiteshvara, the Bodhisattva of Compassion, became feminized in East Asian Buddhism as Guanyin/Kannon. Some scholars have suggested interaction with Christian Marian devotion, though this remains debated.
historicalContext.significance: The development of compassionate divine/semi-divine figures across traditions illustrates universal human longing for divine mercy.

typologicalConnections.observation: Avalokiteshvara embodies compassion that hears the cries of the suffering world. This parallels God who hears prayer (Psalm 34:15) and Christ who has compassion on the multitudes (Matthew 9:36).
typologicalConnections.distinction: Avalokiteshvara is a bodhisattva who delays enlightenment; Christ is God incarnate who definitively saves. Bodhisattva compassion is merit-transferring; Christ's compassion is substitutionary atonement.

typologicalConnections.observation: Avalokiteshvara appears in countless forms to save beings. This has been compared to God's accommodation in revelation.
typologicalConnections.distinction: Christian incarnation is unique and unrepeatable (Hebrews 9:28); Avalokiteshvara's manifestations are ongoing and multiple.

scholarlyEnrichment.methodology: Comparative religion from Christian scholarly perspective, incorporating patristic sources and typological analysis
